Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A major supplier has threatened to halt all future shipments until a significant past-due invoice is settled.
Story:
I woke up early, heart pounding with anticipation and dread. This was the last weekend before Alex left for his new job overseas, and we’d promised to make every moment count. He wanted to go hiking, have brunch at our favorite café, and just be together—no distractions. But as I reached for my phone, I saw a string of urgent emails from work. Our biggest supplier was threatening to stop all shipments unless I resolved a past-due invoice immediately. My manager’s message was clear: I needed to call the supplier and sort things out today, or risk jeopardizing our company’s operations.

Alex was already making coffee, smiling at me, talking about our plans. I tried to focus on him, but my mind kept drifting to spreadsheets and payment deadlines. I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing down on me—my heart aching to be present with Alex, my mind racing with numbers and consequences. I wanted to be the supportive girlfriend he deserved, but I also couldn’t ignore the responsibility of being the accountant my team relied on. The phone buzzed again, and I stared at it, torn, not knowing which role to choose.
